children.content: We investigate the implications of the Baryon Acoustic Oscillation measurements released by the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) for Interacting Dark Energy (IDE) models characterized by an energymomentum flow from Dark Matter to Dark Energy. By combining Planck2018 and DESI data, we observe a preference for interactions exceeding the 95% confidence level, yielding a presentday expansion rate H0=71.4Â±1.5 km/s/Mpc, in agreement with SH0ES. This preference remains robust when including measurements of the expansion rate H(z) obtained from the relative ages of massive, earlytime, and passivelyevolving galaxies, as well as when considering distance moduli measurements from TypeIa Supernovae sourced from the Pantheonplus catalog using the SH0ES Cepheid host distances as calibrators. Overall, high and low redshift data can be equally or better explained within the IDE framework compared to Î›CDM, while also yielding higher values of H0 in better agreement with the local distance ladder estimate.
children.leftover: We investigate the implications of the Baryon Acoustic Oscillation measurements released by the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) for Interacting Dark Energy (IDE) models characterized by an energymomentum flow from Dark Matter to Dark Energy. By combining Planck2018 and DESI data, we observe a preference for interactions exceeding the 95% confidence level, yielding a presentday expansion rate H0=71.4Â±1.5 km/s/Mpc, in agreement with SH0ES. This preference remains robust when including measurements of the expansion rate H(z) obtained from the relative ages of massive, earlytime, and passivelyevolving galaxies, as well as when considering distance moduli measurements from TypeIa Supernovae sourced from the Pantheonplus catalog using the SH0ES Cepheid host distances as calibrators. Overall, high and low redshift data can be equally or better explained within the IDE framework compared to Î›CDM, while also yielding higher values of H0 in better agreement with the local distance ladder estimate.

children.content: The wellknown discrepancy between the presentday expansion rate of the Universe (H0) as measured by the SH0ES collaboration using local distance ladder measurements from Type Ia supernovae (H0=73Â±1 km/s/Mpc), and the value of the same parameter inferred by the Planck collaboration from observations of temperature and polarization anisotropies in the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) radiation, assuming a Î›CDM cosmology (H0=67.4Â±0.5 km/s/Mpc), has reached a statistical significance exceeding 5Ïƒ. Barring any possible systematic origin of this discrepancyThis possibility appears increasingly unlikely given the extensive review of several potential sources of systematic error performed by the SH0ES collaboration., a fascinating possibility is that the Hubble tension might be pointing towards new physics beyond the standard Î›CDM model of cosmology.
children.leftover: The wellknown discrepancy between the presentday expansion rate of the Universe (H0) as measured by the SH0ES collaboration using local distance ladder measurements from Type Ia supernovae (H0=73Â±1 km/s/Mpc), and the value of the same parameter inferred by the Planck collaboration from observations of temperature and polarization anisotropies in the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) radiation, assuming a Î›CDM cosmology (H0=67.4Â±0.5 km/s/Mpc), has reached a statistical significance exceeding 5Ïƒ. Barring any possible systematic origin of this discrepancyThis possibility appears increasingly unlikely given the extensive review of several potential sources of systematic error performed by the SH0ES collaboration., a fascinating possibility is that the Hubble tension might be pointing towards new physics beyond the standard Î›CDM model of cosmology.

children.content: Numerous theoretical attempts have been proposed to increase the value of H0 inferred from CMB data and restore cosmic concordance. However, a compelling solution to the problem remains elusive. The primary challenge stems from the highly precisely determined angular scale of the acoustic peaks in the CMB spectra. This scale sets the ratio between the sound horizon at recombination and the angular diameter distance to the last scattering surface. Increasing the value of H0 without disrupting the acoustic scale requires either a reduction in the value of the sound horizon or a different postrecombination expansion history of the Universe able to compensate for a higher H0 while preserving the angular diameter distance from the last scattering surface.
children.leftover: Numerous theoretical attempts have been proposed to increase the value of H0 inferred from CMB data and restore cosmic concordance. However, a compelling solution to the problem remains elusive. The primary challenge stems from the highly precisely determined angular scale of the acoustic peaks in the CMB spectra. This scale sets the ratio between the sound horizon at recombination and the angular diameter distance to the last scattering surface. Increasing the value of H0 without disrupting the acoustic scale requires either a reduction in the value of the sound horizon or a different postrecombination expansion history of the Universe able to compensate for a higher H0 while preserving the angular diameter distance from the last scattering surface.

children.content: Both of these possibilities face severe constraints. Reducing the value of the sound horizon requires new physics acting at very high redshifts, typically just prior to recombination. Even ignoring the common finetuned problems surrounding earlytime solutions, they remain severely constrained by high redshift observations, most notably by CMB data. Conversely, latetime solutions require new physics altering cosmic distances to compensate for the higher values of H0 while preserving the angular diameter distance from the CMB. In turn, cosmic distances are precisely measured by Baryon Acoustic Oscillations (BAO) and TypeIa supernovae (SN) data that so far have not provided any evidence for deviations from a latetime Î›CDM cosmology, significantly reducing the room allowed for new physics at low redshift.
children.leftover: Both of these possibilities face severe constraints. Reducing the value of the sound horizon requires new physics acting at very high redshifts, typically just prior to recombination. Even ignoring the common finetuned problems surrounding earlytime solutions, they remain severely constrained by high redshift observations, most notably by CMB data. Conversely, latetime solutions require new physics altering cosmic distances to compensate for the higher values of H0 while preserving the angular diameter distance from the CMB. In turn, cosmic distances are precisely measured by Baryon Acoustic Oscillations (BAO) and TypeIa supernovae (SN) data that so far have not provided any evidence for deviations from a latetime Î›CDM cosmology, significantly reducing the room allowed for new physics at low redshift.

children.content: Constraints at 68 (95) CL on the parameters of the IDE model. For all datasets, we provide Î”Ï‡^2 = Ï‡^2IDE  Ï‡^2Î›CDM as well as the Bayes factors lnâ„¬ij = lnğ’µ  lnğ’µIDE calculated as the difference between the evidence for Î›CDM and IDE model. Negative values of Î”Ï‡^2 and lnâ„¬ij indicate a better fit and a preference for the IDE model over the Î›CDM, respectively.

For all datasets, we provide Î”Ï‡^2 = Ï‡^2IDE  Ï‡^2Î›CDM as well as the Bayes factors lnâ„¬ij = lnğ’µ  lnğ’µIDE calculated as the difference between the evidence for Î›CDM and IDE model. Negative values of Î”Ï‡^2 and lnâ„¬ij indicate a better fit and a preference for the IDE model over the Î›CDM, respectively.

children.content: Interestingly, recent BAO measurements released by the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) appear to point towards new physics in the dark energy sector of the cosmological model. Following the intrinsic interest sparked by these new observations, in this letter, we examine their implications for cosmological models known as Interacting Dark Energy (IDE) where a nongravitational interaction between Dark Matter (DM) and Dark Energy (DE) is postulated. Over the years, these models have been extensively explored as a potential avenue for resolving cosmological tensions . Despite highredshift data supporting IDE as solutions to the Hubble tension, the situation remains somewhat unclear when examining lowredshift observations, as different probes yield somewhat discordant conclusions. In this letter, we demonstrate that the new DESI data give a preference for interactions exceeding the 95% confidence level (CL) and that high and lowredshift observations can be equally or better explained in IDE than in Î›CDM, while yielding higher values of H0 compatible with SH0ES. \bigskip
children.leftover: Interestingly, recent BAO measurements released by the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) appear to point towards new physics in the dark energy sector of the cosmological model. Following the intrinsic interest sparked by these new observations, in this letter, we examine their implications for cosmological models known as Interacting Dark Energy (IDE) where a nongravitational interaction between Dark Matter (DM) and Dark Energy (DE) is postulated. Over the years, these models have been extensively explored as a potential avenue for resolving cosmological tensions . Despite highredshift data supporting IDE as solutions to the Hubble tension, the situation remains somewhat unclear when examining lowredshift observations, as different probes yield somewhat discordant conclusions. In this letter, we demonstrate that the new DESI data give a preference for interactions exceeding the 95% confidence level (CL) and that high and lowredshift observations can be equally or better explained in IDE than in Î›CDM, while yielding higher values of H0 compatible with SH0ES. \bigskip

children.content: We consider a homogeneous and isotropic Universe and introduce an energymomentum flow in the dark sector of the model by modifying the energymomentum equation as

children.content: The degree of interaction is quantified by the fourvector
children.leftover: The degree of interaction is quantified by the fourvector

children.content: where u^Î¼ represents the velocity fourvector, Qi is the background energy transfer, and the index i runs over DM and DE. We adopt a widely recognized interaction kernel Q = â„‹Î¾Ï DE where â„‹ is the (conformal) Hubble parameter, Ï DE is the DE energydensity and Î¾ dictates both the amount and the direction of energymomentum flow. We require Î¾ < 0, forcing the energymomentum transfer from DM to DE. Additionally, we fix the DE equation of state to wâ‰ƒ1, resembling an interacting vacuum scenario.~We regularize earlytime superhorizon instabilities in the dynamics of cosmological perturbations by setting w=1+Ïµ and taking Ïµ â‰ƒ 0.0001 â†’0. \bigskip
children.leftover: where u^Î¼ represents the velocity fourvector, Qi is the background energy transfer, and the index i runs over DM and DE. We adopt a widely recognized interaction kernel Q = â„‹Î¾Ï DE where â„‹ is the (conformal) Hubble parameter, Ï DE is the DE energydensity and Î¾ dictates both the amount and the direction of energymomentum flow. We require Î¾ < 0, forcing the energymomentum transfer from DM to DE. Additionally, we fix the DE equation of state to wâ‰ƒ1, resembling an interacting vacuum scenario.~We regularize earlytime superhorizon instabilities in the dynamics of cosmological perturbations by setting w=1+Ïµ and taking Ïµ â‰ƒ 0.0001 â†’0. \bigskip

children.content: We implement the theoretical model in a modified version of the Boltzmann solver code CLASS and use the publicly available sampler COBAYA to perform Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) analyses. We assume flat priors on the set of sampled cosmological parameters {Î©b h^2, Î©c h^2, Ï„ reio, Î¸s, log(10^10 As), ns, Î¾}. Our baseline datasets include the Planck2018 CMB temperature polarization and lensing likelihoods and the DESI BAO measurements obtained from observations of galaxies quasars, and LymanÎ± tracers summarized in Tab.~I of Ref.. These latter are characterized in terms of measurements of the transverse comoving distance (DM/rd), the Hubble horizon (DH/rd), and the angleaveraged distance (DV/rd), normalized to the (comoving) sound horizon at the drag epoch, rd. We account for the correlation between measurements of DM/rd and DH/rd. In addition to CMB and BAO data, we also consider distance moduli measurements from Type Ia SN gathered from the Pantheonplus sample. For this latter we use the SH0ES Cepheid host distances as calibrators. Finally, we include measurements of the expansion rate H(z) derived from the relative ages of massive, earlytime, passivelyevolving galaxies, known as cosmic chronometers (CC). We conservatively use only 15 CC measurements in the redshift range 0.179<z<1.965, accounting for all nondiagonal terms in the covariance matrix and systematic contributions.
children.leftover: We implement the theoretical model in a modified version of the Boltzmann solver code CLASS and use the publicly available sampler COBAYA to perform Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) analyses. We assume flat priors on the set of sampled cosmological parameters {Î©b h^2, Î©c h^2, Ï„ reio, Î¸s, log(10^10 As), ns, Î¾}. Our baseline datasets include the Planck2018 CMB temperature polarization and lensing likelihoods and the DESI BAO measurements obtained from observations of galaxies quasars, and LymanÎ± tracers summarized in Tab.~I of Ref.. These latter are characterized in terms of measurements of the transverse comoving distance (DM/rd), the Hubble horizon (DH/rd), and the angleaveraged distance (DV/rd), normalized to the (comoving) sound horizon at the drag epoch, rd. We account for the correlation between measurements of DM/rd and DH/rd. In addition to CMB and BAO data, we also consider distance moduli measurements from Type Ia SN gathered from the Pantheonplus sample. For this latter we use the SH0ES Cepheid host distances as calibrators. Finally, we include measurements of the expansion rate H(z) derived from the relative ages of massive, earlytime, passivelyevolving galaxies, known as cosmic chronometers (CC). We conservatively use only 15 CC measurements in the redshift range 0.179<z<1.965, accounting for all nondiagonal terms in the covariance matrix and systematic contributions.

children.content: 2D contours at 68 and 95 CL for the coupling parameter Î¾ and the Hubble parameter H0, as inferred by the different combinations of Planck2018, DESI, and SN data listed in the legend. The olivegreen band represents the value of H0 measured by the SH0ES collaboration.

children.content: Upper panel: Bestfit predictions for (rescaled) distanceredshift relations for IDE (solid curves) and Î›CDM (dashed curves) obtained from the analysis of Planck2018+DESI data. These predictions are presented for the three different types of distances probed by BAO measurements, each indicated by the colors reported in the legend. The error bars represent Â± 1 Ïƒ uncertainties. Lower panel: Difference between the model prediction and datapoint for each BAO measurement, normalized by the observational uncertainties. The IDE predictions are represented by 'x'shaped points while the Î›CDM predictions are represented by 'o'shaped points.

The IDE predictions are represented by 'x'shaped points while the Î›CDM predictions are represented by 'o'shaped points.

children.content: We summarize the constraints on cosmological parameters at 68% and 95% CL in Tab.. The most important results read as follows:
children.leftover: We summarize the constraints on cosmological parameters at 68% and 95% CL in Tab.. The most important results read as follows:

children.content: The joint Planck+DESI analysis yields a preference for a nonvanishing Î¾ = 0.38^+0.180.16, well exceeding the 95% CL. Additionally, it provides a value H0 = 71.4 Â± 1.5 km/s/Mpc, in perfect agreement with local distance ladder estimates. Therefore, focusing on Planck2018 and DESIBAO altogether, IDE can fully resolve the Hubble tension, see also Fig.. Adding CC does not change this result, see also Tab.. Combining Planck2018+DESI+SN, we still find a preference for Î¾â‰  0 at more than 95% CL, consistently yielding values of H0 higher than in the standard cosmological model, see also Tab. and Fig.. Again, this conclusion does not change considering CC. A nonvanishing energymomentum flow from DM to DE is potentially supported by all the main high and low redshift datasets analyzed in this work. For all the datasets listed in Tab., we compare the bestfit Ï‡^2IDE obtained within IDE to the bestfit Ï‡^2Î›CDM obtained for Î›CDM. We find that Î”Ï‡^2 = Ï‡^2IDE  Ï‡^2Î›CDM is always negative. This means that IDE can fit data better than Î›CDM for all the different combinations of data while simultaneously yielding higher values of H0. To account for the fact that IDE has one more free parameter than Î›CDM, we perform a model comparison and calculate the Bayes factors lnâ„¬ij normalized (for each dataset) to a baseline Î›CDM scenario in such a way that a negative lnâ„¬ij indicate a preference for IDE over Î›CDM, and vice versa.To do so, we employ the MCEvidence package, which is publicly available and can be accessed at the following link: https://github.com/yabebalFantaye/MCEvidence. Despite a trend towards lnâ„¬ij < 0, the evidence is always inconclusive, suggesting that IDE and Î›CDM can be deemed equally plausible to fit current observations.

This means that IDE can fit data better than Î›CDM for all the different combinations of data while simultaneously yielding higher values of H0. To account for the fact that IDE has one more free parameter than Î›CDM, we perform a model comparison and calculate the Bayes factors lnâ„¬ij normalized (for each dataset) to a baseline Î›CDM scenario in such a way that a negative lnâ„¬ij indicate a preference for IDE over Î›CDM, and vice versa.To do so, we employ the MCEvidence package, which is publicly available and can be accessed at the following link: https://github.com/yabebalFantaye/MCEvidence. Despite a trend towards lnâ„¬ij < 0, the evidence is always inconclusive, suggesting that IDE and Î›CDM can be deemed equally plausible to fit current observations.

children.content: The DESI results (and their 1Ïƒ errors) are presented for three distinct types of distances investigated by BAO measurements. For each data point, we indicate the consistency between the bestfit predictions of the IDE and Î›CDM models and the observed data, expressed in units of observational uncertainties (# Ïƒ).
children.leftover: The DESI results (and their 1Ïƒ errors) are presented for three distinct types of distances investigated by BAO measurements. For each data point, we indicate the consistency between the bestfit predictions of the IDE and Î›CDM models and the observed data, expressed in units of observational uncertainties (# Ïƒ).

children.content: Taking the results obtained by combining Planck2018 and DESI BAO distance measurements at face value, there is solid ground to conclude that they lend weight to the possibility of nonvanishing energymomentum transfer from DM to DE, resulting in the pronounced negative correlation between Î¾ and H0 depicted in Fig.. This preference can be better understood by referring to Ref.. In this work, the DESI collaboration argued that both within a minimal w0CDM model and considering a dynamical w0waCDM parameterization, Planck2018+DESI data produce a strong preference for a (dynamical) DE equation of state showing a phantom behavior in the past. In IDE, upon straightforward manipulation of the continuity equation, one can rearrange the effective equation of state parameters to be weff = 1 + Î¾/3. Consequently, the preference for a latetime phantomlike behavior is recast into an indication Î¾ < 0 here exceeding the 95% CL. Focusing on Planck+DESI(+CC), this preference can fully resolve the Hubble tension. However, the significant tion of energymomentum transferred from DM to DE naturally implies lower values of the matter density parameter (Î©m) compared to the standard cosmological model. When SN data are included in the analysis, we observe a tendency towards higher values of Î©m that reduces the value inferred for H0. Having that said, H0 always remains significantly larger than the value inferred within the standard cosmological model and in much better agreement with local distance ladder estimate.
children.leftover: Taking the results obtained by combining Planck2018 and DESI BAO distance measurements at face value, there is solid ground to conclude that they lend weight to the possibility of nonvanishing energymomentum transfer from DM to DE, resulting in the pronounced negative correlation between Î¾ and H0 depicted in Fig.. This preference can be better understood by referring to Ref.. In this work, the DESI collaboration argued that both within a minimal w0CDM model and considering a dynamical w0waCDM parameterization, Planck2018+DESI data produce a strong preference for a (dynamical) DE equation of state showing a phantom behavior in the past. In IDE, upon straightforward manipulation of the continuity equation, one can rearrange the effective equation of state parameters to be weff = 1 + Î¾/3. Consequently, the preference for a latetime phantomlike behavior is recast into an indication Î¾ < 0 here exceeding the 95% CL. Focusing on Planck+DESI(+CC), this preference can fully resolve the Hubble tension. However, the significant tion of energymomentum transferred from DM to DE naturally implies lower values of the matter density parameter (Î©m) compared to the standard cosmological model. When SN data are included in the analysis, we observe a tendency towards higher values of Î©m that reduces the value inferred for H0. Having that said, H0 always remains significantly larger than the value inferred within the standard cosmological model and in much better agreement with local distance ladder estimate.

children.content: To better understand the role played by DESI data, we compare the theoretical distance predictions for IDE and Î›CDM against the observed cosmic distances. In particular, in Fig., we compare the Planck2018+DESI bestfit predictions for the three different types of (rescaled) distances probed by BAO measurements. In the bottom panel of the same figure, we show the distance between the observed DESI data points and the bestfit predictions obtained for Î›CDM ('o'shaped points) and IDE ('x'shaped points) in units of observational uncertainty Ïƒ. The same difference between the model predictions and DESI data is summarized in Tab.. Comparing the bestfit predictions for IDE and Î›CDM, some important conclusions can be reached. Foremost, we see that the only two data points that are in disagreement with IDE at a level exceeding 2Ïƒ are the measurements of DM(z)/(rd âˆš(z)) and z DH(z) / (rdâˆš(z)) at z=0.51. However, the same two (correlated) data points are also in significant disagreement with Î›CDM, especially z DH(z) / (rdâˆš(z)). Conversely, IDE is more successful in explaining DM(z)/(rd âˆš(z)) at z=0.71 than Î›CDM. Overall, apart from the DESI distance measurements at z=0.51 (which  repetita iuvant  are at odds also with Î›CDM), there are no other BAO measurements in tension with the IDE bestfit predictions. Remarkably, the bestfit value for H0âˆ¼ 73.26 obtained by Planck2018+DESI is fully consistent with SH0ES. Last but not least, we stress that for Planck2018+BAO, the larger part of the improvement in the total Î”Ï‡^2=2.33 over Î›CDM comes exactly from the DESI BAO measurement (Î”Ï‡^2DESI=1.52)For Planck2018+DESI+CC, such improvement in the fit of DESI BAO measurements becomes even more significant: Î”Ï‡^2DESI=2.34..
children.leftover: To better understand the role played by DESI data, we compare the theoretical distance predictions for IDE and Î›CDM against the observed cosmic distances. In particular, in Fig., we compare the Planck2018+DESI bestfit predictions for the three different types of (rescaled) distances probed by BAO measurements. In the bottom panel of the same figure, we show the distance between the observed DESI data points and the bestfit predictions obtained for Î›CDM ('o'shaped points) and IDE ('x'shaped points) in units of observational uncertainty Ïƒ. The same difference between the model predictions and DESI data is summarized in Tab.. Comparing the bestfit predictions for IDE and Î›CDM, some important conclusions can be reached. Foremost, we see that the only two data points that are in disagreement with IDE at a level exceeding 2Ïƒ are the measurements of DM(z)/(rd âˆš(z)) and z DH(z) / (rdâˆš(z)) at z=0.51. However, the same two (correlated) data points are also in significant disagreement with Î›CDM, especially z DH(z) / (rdâˆš(z)). Conversely, IDE is more successful in explaining DM(z)/(rd âˆš(z)) at z=0.71 than Î›CDM. Overall, apart from the DESI distance measurements at z=0.51 (which  repetita iuvant  are at odds also with Î›CDM), there are no other BAO measurements in tension with the IDE bestfit predictions. Remarkably, the bestfit value for H0âˆ¼ 73.26 obtained by Planck2018+DESI is fully consistent with SH0ES. Last but not least, we stress that for Planck2018+BAO, the larger part of the improvement in the total Î”Ï‡^2=2.33 over Î›CDM comes exactly from the DESI BAO measurement (Î”Ï‡^2DESI=1.52)For Planck2018+DESI+CC, such improvement in the fit of DESI BAO measurements becomes even more significant: Î”Ï‡^2DESI=2.34..

children.content: As a final remark, in Fig., we present the theoretical predictions for H(z) as obtained by simultaneously analyzing Planck2018, DESI, CC, and SN. We display the bestfit predictions (along with their 1 and 2Ïƒ uncertainties) for IDE and Î›CDM, comparing them against the data points released by DESI. As evident from the figure, even accounting for all datasets together, the DESI datapoint at z=0.51 remains essentially unexplained in both models. Conversely, IDE can fit H(z) at z=0.71 and z=0.93 better than Î›CDM, simultaneously predicting a larger presentday expansion rate H0, as evident when comparing the red and blue reconstructed curves at z=0.
children.leftover: As a final remark, in Fig., we present the theoretical predictions for H(z) as obtained by simultaneously analyzing Planck2018, DESI, CC, and SN. We display the bestfit predictions (along with their 1 and 2Ïƒ uncertainties) for IDE and Î›CDM, comparing them against the data points released by DESI. As evident from the figure, even accounting for all datasets together, the DESI datapoint at z=0.51 remains essentially unexplained in both models. Conversely, IDE can fit H(z) at z=0.71 and z=0.93 better than Î›CDM, simultaneously predicting a larger presentday expansion rate H0, as evident when comparing the red and blue reconstructed curves at z=0.

children.content: In conclusion, barring any potential systematic errors, BAO measurements released by DESI significantly open up the possibility of addressing the Hubble tension through latetime new physics, as argued here for IDE.
children.leftover: In conclusion, barring any potential systematic errors, BAO measurements released by DESI significantly open up the possibility of addressing the Hubble tension through latetime new physics, as argued here for IDE.

children.content: Statistical reconstruction of the (rescaled) expansion rate of the universe H(z)/(1+z) at 1Ïƒ and 2Ïƒ confidence levels for Î›CDM and IDE models through the joint analysis of Planck2018+DESI+SN+CC, compared to DESI measurements.
children.leftover: Statistical reconstruction of the (rescaled) expansion rate of the universe H(z)/(1+z) at 1Ïƒ and 2Ïƒ confidence levels for Î›CDM and IDE models through the joint analysis of Planck2018+DESI+SN+CC, compared to DESI measurements.

children.content: In this letter, we have studied the implications of the Baryon Acoustic Oscillations measurements released by the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument for Interacting Dark Energy models characterized by an energymomentum flow from Dark Matter to Dark Energy. Focusing on the minimal Planck2018+DESI data combination, we found a preference for interactions exceeding the 95% confidence level, yielding a presentday expansion rate H0=71.4Â±1.5 km/s/Mpc which can resolve the Hubble tension. Combining Planck2018+DESI with either measurements of the expansion rate H(z) obtained from the relative ages of massive, earlytime, and passivelyevolving galaxies or with distance moduli measurements from TypeIa Supernovae sourced from the Pantheonplus catalog using the SH0ES Cepheid host distances as a calibrator, we still find a preference for Î¾â‰  0 at more than 95% CL. For all the different combinations of datasets, we observe an improvement in the Ï‡^2 of the fit over Î›CDM. Overall, accounting for DESI measurements, high and low redshift data are found to be equally or better explained within the IDE framework than Î›CDM, while consistently yielding values of H0 that are higher than in the standard cosmological model and in much better agreement with local distance ladder estimates. In light of these results, we conclude that DESI data (re)open up the possibility of addressing the Hubble tension through latetime new physics.
children.leftover: In this letter, we have studied the implications of the Baryon Acoustic Oscillations measurements released by the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument for Interacting Dark Energy models characterized by an energymomentum flow from Dark Matter to Dark Energy. Focusing on the minimal Planck2018+DESI data combination, we found a preference for interactions exceeding the 95% confidence level, yielding a presentday expansion rate H0=71.4Â±1.5 km/s/Mpc which can resolve the Hubble tension. Combining Planck2018+DESI with either measurements of the expansion rate H(z) obtained from the relative ages of massive, earlytime, and passivelyevolving galaxies or with distance moduli measurements from TypeIa Supernovae sourced from the Pantheonplus catalog using the SH0ES Cepheid host distances as a calibrator, we still find a preference for Î¾â‰  0 at more than 95% CL. For all the different combinations of datasets, we observe an improvement in the Ï‡^2 of the fit over Î›CDM. Overall, accounting for DESI measurements, high and low redshift data are found to be equally or better explained within the IDE framework than Î›CDM, while consistently yielding values of H0 that are higher than in the standard cosmological model and in much better agreement with local distance ladder estimates. In light of these results, we conclude that DESI data (re)open up the possibility of addressing the Hubble tension through latetime new physics.
